column2: also called the Jasmine Revolution
column3: was an intensive 28-day campaign of civil resistance. It included a series of street demonstrations which took place in Tunisia
column4: and led to the ousting of longtime president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali in January 2011. It eventually led to a thorough democratisation of the country and to free and democratic elections.The demonstrations were caused by high unemployment
column5: food inflation
column7: a lack of political freedoms (such as freedom of speech) and poor living conditions. The protests constituted the most dramatic wave of social and political unrest in Tunisia in three decades and resulted in scores of deaths and injuries
column8: most of which were the result of action by police and security forces.

column1: The protests were sparked by the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi on 17 December 2010. They led to the ousting of Ben Ali on 14 January 2011
column2: when he officially resigned after fleeing to Saudi Arabia
column3: ending his 23 years in power. Labor unions were an integral part of the protests. The Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet was awarded the 2015 Nobel Peace Prize for "its decisive contribution to the building of a pluralistic democracy in Tunisia in the wake of the Tunisian Revolution of 2011". The protests inspired similar actions throughout the Arab world
column4: in a chain reaction which became known as the Arab Spring movement.

column1: In Tunisia and the wider Arab world
column2: the protests and change in government are called the Revolution or sometimes the Sidi Bouzid Revolt
column3: the name being derived from Sidi Bouzid
column4: the city where the initial protests began. In the Western media
column5: these events have been dubbed the Jasmine Revolution or Jasmine Spring
column6: after Tunisia's national flower and in keeping with the geopolitical nomenclature of "color revolutions". The name "Jasmine Revolution" originated from American journalist Andy Carvin
column7: but it was not widely adopted in Tunisia itself.The protests and resultant political crises have generally been called the Jasmine revolution only in the foreign media. Tunisian philosopher Youssef Seddik deemed the term inappropriate because the violence that accompanied the event was "perhaps as deep as Bastille Day"
column8: and although the term was coined by the Tunisian journalist Zied El Hani
column9: who first used it on his blog on 13 January and initially spread via social media such as Facebook (hence "Revolution Facebook" among the youth of Tunisia)
column10: it is not in widespread use in Tunisia itself.The debate surrounding the name and the poetic influences behind the Tunisian revolution was a popular question among Tunisian intellectuals. The name adopted in Tunisia was the Dignity Revolution
column11: which is a translation of the Tunisian Arabic name for the revolution
column13: Ben Ali's rise to power in 1987 was also known as the Jasmine Revolution.

column1: President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali had ruled Tunisia since 1987
column2: mostly as a one-party state with the Democratic Constitutional Rally (RCD). His government was characterised by the development of Tunisia's private sector in favor of foreign investment
column3: and the repression of political opposition. Foreign media and NGOs criticised his government
column4: which was supported by the United States and France. As a result
column5: the initial reactions to Ben Ali's abuses by the U.S. and France were muted
column6: and most instances of socio-political protest in the country
column8: rarely made major news headlines.Riots in Tunisia were rare and noteworthy
column9: especially since the country is generally considered to be wealthy and stable as compared to other countries in the region. Protests had been repressed and kept silent by the regime
column10: and protesters would be jailed for such actions
column11: as with hundreds of unemployed demonstrators in Redeyef in 2008. As noted by Mohamed Bacha in his book The Revolutionary Chants of Club Africain Ultras
column12: Tunisian youth had found an outlet to express their anger and dissatisfaction
column13: through the fan chants of sports association Club Africain Ultras
column14: such as: The capital is very angry
column15: We are solidary when we make war to the sons of --- Who oppress us

column1: At the time of the revolution
column2: Al Jazeera English reported that Tunisian activists are among the most outspoken in its part of the world
column3: with various messages of support being posted on Twitter and facebook for Bouazizi. An op-ed article in the same network said of the action that it was "suicidal protests of despair by Tunisia's youth." It pointed out that the state-controlled National Solidarity Fund and the National Employment Fund had traditionally subsidised many goods and services in the country but had started to shift the "burden of providence from state to society" to be funded by the bidonvilles
column4: or shanty towns
column5: around the richer towns and suburbs. It also cited the "marginalisation of the agrarian and arid central
column6: northern west and southern areas [that] continue[s] unabated." The protests were also called an "uprising" because of "a lethal combination of poverty
column8: and political repression: three characteristics of most Arab societies." It was a revolution
column10: "started not by the middle class or the northern urban centers

column1: Twenty-six-year-old Mohamed Bouazizi had been the sole income earner in his extended family of eight. He operated a vegetable or apple cart (the contents of the cart are disputed) for seven years in Sidi Bouzid
column2: 300 kilometres (190 miles) south of Tunis. On 17 December 2010
column3: a female officer confiscated his cart and produce. Bouazizi
column4: who had had such an event happen to him before
column5: tried to pay the 10-dinars fine (a day's wages
column6: equivalent to US$3). It was initially reported that in response the policewoman insulted his deceased father and slapped him. This was a false story
column7: which "had been disseminated and used to mobilise as much as possible against the Ben Ali regime." The officer
column9: stated that she was not even a policewoman
column10: but a city employee who had been tasked that morning with confiscating produce from vendors without licenses. When she tried to do so with Bouazizi
column11: a scuffle ensued. Hamdi says she called the police who then beat Bouazizi.A humiliated Bouazizi then went to the provincial headquarters in an attempt to complain to local municipality officials and to have his produce returned. He was refused an audience. Without alerting his family
column12: at 11:30 am and within an hour of the initial confrontation
column14: doused himself with a flammable liquid and set himself on fire. Public outrage quickly grew over the incident
column16: and the subsequent heavy-handed response by the police to peaceful marchers
column17: provoked riots the next day in Sidi Bouzid. The riots went largely unnoticed
column18: though social media sites diseminated images of police dispersing youths who attacked shop windows and damaged cars. Bouazizi was subsequently transferred to a hospital near Tunis. In an attempt to quell the unrest
column19: President Ben Ali visited Bouazizi in hospital on 28 December. Bouazizi died on 4 January 2011.Sociologist Asef Bayat
column20: who visited Tunisia after the uprising and carried out field research
column21: wrote about the mechanisation of large-scale capitalist farms in towns like Sidi Bouzid that have come "at the cost of smallholders' debt
column23: and proletarianization." Tunisian geographer-cinematographer Habib Ayeb
column24: founder of the Tunisian Observatory for Food Sovereignty and the Environment (OSAE)
column25: has questioned the model of development that was introduced in Sidi Bouzid:

column1: [The region] received the most investment between 1990 and 2011. The leading region. It is a region that had an extensive semi-pastoral farming system
column2: and it became in less than 30 years the premier agricultural region of the country. At the same time Sidi Bouzid had been a "moderately poor" region
column3: in a sense
column4: and I put that in quotation marks
column5: and it is now the fourth-poorest region in the country. This is the development which people desire... The problem is that the local population does not benefit. These are people from Sfax and the Sahel who get rich in Sidi Bouzid
column6: not the people of Sidi Bouzid. Hence the link with the story of Mohamed Bouazizi.

The protesters had gathered outside regional government headquarters to demonstrate against the treatment of Mohamed Bouazizi. Coverage of events was limited by Tunisian media. On 19 December

column16: whose songs had been adopted by protesters

column32: the protesters were reported to have set fire to tyres and attacked the RCD offices. Some of the more general protests sought changes in the government's online censorship; Tunisian authorities allegedly carried out phishing operations to take control of user passwords and check online criticism. Both state and non-state websites had been hacked.On 6 January 95% of Tunisia's 8
column34: according to the chairman of the national bar association. He said
column35: "The strike carries a clear message that we do not accept unjustified attacks on lawyers. We want to strongly protest against the beating of lawyers in the past few days." It was reported on the following day that teachers had also joined the strike.In response to 11 January protests
column36: police used riot gear to disperse protesters ransacking buildings
column38: setting fire to a bus and burning two cars in the Tunis working-class suburb of Ettadhamen-Mnihla. The protesters were said to have chanted "We are not afraid
column40: we are afraid only of God". Military personnel were also deployed in many cities around the country.On 12 January
column41: a reporter from Italian broadcaster RAI stated that he and his cameraman were beaten with batons by police during a riot in Tunis's central district and that the officers then confiscated their camera. A curfew was ordered in Tunis after protests and clashes with police.Hizb ut-Tahrir organised protests after Friday prayer on 14 January to call for re-establishing the Islamic caliphate. A day later
column42: it also organised other protests that marched to the 9 April Prison to free political prisoners.Also on 14 January
column44: a photojournalist for the European Pressphoto Agency
column45: was hit in the forehead by a tear gas canister allegedly fired by the police at short range; he died two days later.

column1: During a national television broadcast on 28 December
column2: President Ben Ali criticised protesters as "extremists and mercenaries" and warned of "firm" punishment. He also accused "certain foreign television channels" of spreading falsehoods and deforming the truth
column3: and called them "hostile to Tunisia". His remarks were ignored and the protests continued.On 29 December
column4: Ben Ali shuffled his cabinet to remove communications minister Oussama Romdhani
column5: while also announcing changes to the trade and handicrafts
column7: communication and youth portfolios. The next day he also announced the dismissal of the governors of Sidi Bouzid
column11: though he did not clarify what that meant. He described the protests as "the work of masked gangs" attacking public property and citizens in their homes
column12: and "a terrorist act that cannot be overlooked". Ahmed Najib Chebbi
column13: the leader of the Progressive Democratic Party (PDP)
column14: responded that despite official claims of police firing in self-defense "the demonstrations were non-violent and the youths were claiming their rights to jobs" and that "the funeral processions [for those killed on 9 January] turned into demonstrations
column15: and the police fired [at] the youths who were at these [...] processions." He then criticised Ben Ali's comments as the protesters were "claiming their civil rights
column16: and there is no terrorist act...no religious slogans". He further accused Ben Ali of "looking for scapegoats" and dismissed the creation of jobs as mere promises.Several webloggers and rapper El Général were arrested
column17: but the rapper and some of the bloggers were later released. Reporters Without Borders said the arrest of at least six bloggers and activists
column18: who had either been arrested or had disappeared across Tunisia
column19: was brought to their attention and that there were "probably" others. Tunisian Pirate Party activists Slah Eddine Kchouk
column20: Slim Amamou (later appointed Secretary of State for Sport and Youth by the incoming government) and Azyz Amamy were arrested but later released. Hamma Hammami
column21: the leader of the banned Tunisian Workers' Communist Party and a prominent critic of Ben Ali
column23: and released two days later.On 10 January
column24: the government announced the indefinite closure of all schools and universities in order to quell the unrest. Days before departing office
column25: Ben Ali announced that he would not change the present constitution
column26: which would require him to step down in 2014 due to his age.On 14 January
column27: Ben Ali dissolved his government and declared a state of emergency. The official reason given was to protect Tunisians and their property. People were barred from gathering in groups of more than three
column28: and could be arrested or shot if they tried to run away. Ben Ali called for an election within six months to defuse demonstrations aimed at forcing him out. France24 reported that the military took control of the airport and closed the country's airspace.

column2: Ben Ali fled the country for Malta under Libyan protection. His aircraft landed in Jeddah
column3: Saudi Arabia
column4: after France rejected a request to land on its territory. Saudi Arabia cited "exceptional circumstances" for their heavily criticised decision to give him asylum
column5: saying it was also "in support of the security and stability of their country". Saudi Arabia demanded Ben Ali remain "out of politics" as a condition for accepting him.

column1: == Initial impact of Ben Ali's overthrow ==
Following Ben Ali's departure from the country
column2: a state of emergency was declared. Army Commander Rashid Ammar pledged to "protect the revolution". Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi then briefly took over as acting president. On the morning of 15 January
column3: Tunisian state TV announced that Ben Ali had officially resigned his position and Ghannouchi had handed over the presidency to parliamentary speaker Fouad Mebazaa
column4: with Ghannouchi returning to his previous position as prime minister. This was done after the head of Tunisia's Constitutional Court
column5: Fethi Abdennadher
column6: declared that Ghannouchi did not have right to power
column7: and confirmed Fouad Mebazaa as acting President under Article 57 of the constitution. Mebazaa was given 60 days to organise new elections. Mebazaa said it was in the country's best interest to form a national unity government.INTERPOL confirmed that its National Central Bureau (NCB) in Tunis had issued a global alert to find and arrest Ben Ali and six of his relatives.A commission to reform the constitution and law in general was set up under Yadh Ben Achour. There were also calls by the opposition to delay the elections
column8: holding them in six or seven months with international supervision.

column2: violence and looting continued and the capital's main train station was torched. The national army was reported to be extensively deployed in Tunisia
column3: including elements loyal to Ben Ali.A prison director in Mahdia freed about 1
column4: 000 inmates following a prison rebellion that left 5 people dead. Many other prisons also had jailbreaks or raids from external groups to force prisoner releases
column5: some suspected to be aided by prison guards. Residents who were running out of necessary food supplies had armed themselves and barricaded their homes
column6: and in some cases had formed armed neighborhood watches. Al Jazeera's correspondent said there were apparently three different armed groups: the police (numbering 250
column8: security forces from the Interior Ministry
column9: and irregular militias supportive of Ben Ali who were vying for control.Ali Seriati
column11: was arrested and accused of threatening state security by fomenting violence. Following this
column12: gun battles took place near the Presidential Palace between the Tunisian army and elements of security organs loyal to the former regime. The Tunisian army was reportedly struggling to assert control. Gunfire continued in Tunis and Carthage as security services struggled to maintain law and order.The most immediate result of the protests was seen in increased Internet freedoms. While commentators were divided about the extent to which the Internet contributed to the ousting of Ben Ali
column13: Facebook remained accessible to roughly 20% of the population throughout the crisis whilst its passwords were hacked by a country-wide man-in-the-middle attack. YouTube and DailyMotion became available after Ben Ali's ouster
column14: and the Tor anonymity network reported a surge of traffic from Tunisia.

column1: The Ghannouchi administration (15 January – 27 February 2011) was a caretaker government with the primary goal of maintaining the state and providing a legal framework for new elections.
Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi announced his cabinet on 17 January 2011
column2: three days after Ben Ali's departure. The cabinet included twelve members of the ruling RCD
column3: the leaders of three opposition parties (Mustapha Ben Jafar from the Democratic Forum for Labour and Liberties [FTDL]
column4: Ahmed Brahim of the Ettajdid Movement
column5: and Ahmed Najib Chebbi of the PDP)
column6: three representatives from the Tunisian General Labour Union (UGTT)
column7: and representatives of civil society (including prominent blogger Slim Amamou). Three notable movements not included in the national unity government were the banned Ennahda Movement
column8: the Tunisian Workers' Communist Party and the secular reformist Congress for the Republic. The following day
column9: the three members of the UGTT and Ben Jafaar resigned
column10: saying that they had "no confidence" in a government featuring members of the RCD.There were daily protests that members of Ben Ali's RCD party were in the new government. Thousands of anti-RCD protesters rallied in a protests with relatively little violence. On 18 January
column15: Sousse and Monastir. Ghannouchi and interim president Mebazaa resigned their RCD memberships in a bid to calm protests
column16: and Ghannouchi stated that all members of the national unity government had "clean hands".On 20 January
column18: a close confidant of Ben Ali
column19: resigned from the government. All other RCD ministers resigned from the party and the central committee of the RCD disbanded itself. The new government announced in its first sitting that all political prisoners would be freed and all banned parties would be legalised. The next day
column20: Ghannouchi committed to resigning after holding transparent and free elections within six months.Police began to join the protests in Tunis on 23 January over salaries
column21: and to deflect blame over political deaths attributed to them during Ben Ali's rule. Army chief Rachid Ammar declares that the armed forces are also on the side of the protesters and would "defend the revolution".On 27 January
column23: with six former-RCD members departing the interim government. Only Ghannouchi and the ministers of industry and international cooperation (who had not been RCD members) remained from Ben Ali's old government. This was seen as meeting one of the protesters' demands
column24: and the UGTT stated its support for the reorganised cabinet. New ministers included state attorney Farhat Rajhi as interior minister
column25: retired career diplomat Ahmed Ounaies as foreign minister
column26: and economist Elyes Jouini as minister delegate to the prime minister in charge of administrative and economic reform. Ounaies later resigned after praising a foreign politician with ties to Ben Ali. Mouldi Kefi became the new foreign minister on 21 February.By 3 February
column27: all 24 regional governors had been replaced. Days later
column28: the government reached an agreement with the UGTT on the nomination of new governors. The Interior Ministry replaced 34 top-level security officials who were a part of Ben Ali's security infrastructure. Mebazaa promised a national dialogue to address protester demands.Sidi Bouzid and El Kef saw violence in early February with protesters killed and a police car set on fire. A local police chief was arrested.

column2: the defense ministry called up soldiers discharged in the previous five years to help control unrest.The first steps were taken on a bill that would give Mebazaa emergency powers
column3: allowing him to bypass the RCD-dominated parliament. The bill would allow Mebazaa to ratify international human-rights treaties without parliament; he had previously stated that Tunisia would accede to the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance
column4: the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court
column5: the Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and other Cruel
column6: Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment
column7: and the First and Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (which would mean abolishing the death penalty).Reports emerged on 18 February that Ben Ali had had a stroke and was gravely ill. Plans for a general amnesty were also announced on that day.Protests flared on 19 February
column9: 000 protesters demanding a new interim government completely free of association with the old regime
column10: and a parliamentary system of government replacing the current presidential one.

column1: As a date was announced for an election in mid-July 2011
column2: more than 100
column3: 000 protesters demanded the removal of Ghannouchi. On 27 February
column4: following a day of clashes in which five protesters were killed
column5: Ghannouchi resigned. He stated that he had carried his responsibilities since Ben Ali fled
column6: and "I am not ready to be the person who takes decisions that would end up causing casualties. This resignation will serve Tunisia
column7: and the revolution and the future of Tunisia."

column1: Béji Caïd Essebsi became prime minister
column2: appointed by Mebazaa on the day Ghannouchi resigned. Although the cabinet was now free of RCD members
column3: demonstrations continued as the protesters criticized the unilateral appointment of Essebsi without consultation.Ghannouchi's resignation was followed the next day by the resignations of industry minister Afif Chelbi and international co-operation minister Mohamed Nouri Jouini. There were now protests for the entire interim government to resign
column4: with the UGTT calling for an elected constituent assembly to write a new constitution. Further resignations were reported on 1 March: minister for higher education and scientific research Ahmed Brahim
column5: minister of local development Ahmed Nejib Chebbi
column6: and minister of economic reform Elyes Jouini.Mebazaa announced elections to a Constituent Assembly would be held on 24 July 2011. This would likely postpone general elections to a later date. This fulfilled a central demand of protesters.In early March
column7: the interim government announced that the secret police would be dissolved. A Tunis court announced the dissolution of the RCD and liquidation of its assets
column8: though the party said it would appeal the decision.In mid-April
column9: charges were announced against Ben Ali
column10: for whom international arrest warrants were issued in January. There were 18 charges
column11: including voluntary manslaughter and drug trafficking. His family and former ministers faced 26 further charges.The elections were further postponed and ultimately held on 23 October 2011. The election appointed members to a Constituent Assembly charged with rewriting Tunisia's Constitution. The formerly banned Islamic party Ennahda
column13: won with 41% of the total vote.

column2: about 4
column3: 000 mostly Tunisian refugees landed on the Italian island of Lampedusa
column4: causing the authorities to declare a state of emergency that would allow for federal aid to the island. Italian Interior Minister Roberto Maroni accused the EU of not doing enough to curb immigration and asked them to do more. He said that the "Tunisian system was collapsing" and that he would "ask the Tunisian Foreign Ministry for permission for our authorities to intervene to stop the flow in Tunisia"
column5: suggesting Italian troops would be on Tunisian soil. He called the event a "biblical exodus". The comments started a row between the two countries with the Tunisian Foreign Ministry saying it was ready to work with Italy and others but that it "categorically rejects any interference in its internal affairs or any infringement of its sovereignty." In response
column6: Italy's Foreign Minister Franco Frattini said that both countries share a "common interest" to halt the immigration
column7: while he also offered "logistical help in terms of police and equipment" and called to re-establish previously successful coastal patrols of Northern Africa. By 14 February
column9: 000 refugees had been sent to Sicily with the other 2
column10: 000 quarantined at a re-opened holding center. On 2 March about 350 more people arrived on the island. In response
column11: Italy declared a humanitarian emergency.The International Organisation for Migration said that no new boats had been spotted. The EU's Catherine Ashton was on a visit to Tunisia to discuss the issue. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said that "not everyone who does not want to be in Tunisia can come to Europe. Rather
column12: we need to talk to each other how we can strengthen the rule of law in Tunisia again and whether Europe can be of help."

column2: the Bourse de Tunis (TUNINDEX)
column3: fell on 12 January for a three consecutive day loss of 9.3%. Following the curfew in Tunis
column4: the market index again fell 3.8% as the cost of protecting against a sovereign default in credit default swaps rose to its highest level in almost two years.Following the resignations of Ghanoucchi and two Ben Ali-era ministers
column5: the bourse was again suspended.

column1: Many governments and supranational organisations expressed concerns over use of force against protesters. France
column2: the former colonial power of Tunisia
column3: was one of just a few states that expressed strong support for the Ben Ali government prior to its ouster
column4: though protests were held in solidarity with Tunisia in several French cities and the French Socialist Party voiced support for the popular revolution.

column1: The lack of coverage in the domestic state-controlled media was criticised. Writer/activist Jillian York alleged that the mainstream media
column2: particularly in the Western world
column3: was providing less coverage and less sympathetic coverage to the Tunisia protests relative to Iranian protests
column4: the Green movement
column5: and censorship in China. York alleged the "US government – which intervened heavily in Iran
column6: approving circumvention technology for export and famously asking Twitter to halt updates during a critical time period – has not made any public overtures toward Tunisia at this time."Despite criticism about the "sparse" level of coverage and "little interest" given to the demonstrations by the international media
column7: the protests were hailed by some commentators as "momentous events" in Tunisian history. Brian Whitaker
column8: writing in The Guardian on 28 December 2010
column9: suggested that the protests would be enough to bring an end to Ben Ali's presidency and noted similarities with the protests that led to the end of Nicolae Ceauşescu's reign in Romania in 1989. Steven Cook
column10: writing for the Council of Foreign Relations
column11: noted that a tipping point is only obvious after the fact
column12: and pointed to the counter-example of the 2009–2010 Iranian election protests. Ben Ali's governing strategy was nevertheless regarded as being in serious trouble
column13: and Elliot Abrams noted both that demonstrators were able for the first time to defy the security forces and that the regime had no obvious successors to Ben Ali and his family.

column1: French management of the crisis came under severe criticism
column2: with notable silence in the mainstream media in the run-up to the crisis.

column1: Al Jazeera believed the ousting of the president meant the "glass ceiling of fear has been for ever shattered in Tunisia and that the police state that Ben Ali created in 1987 when he came to power in a coup seems to be disintegrating". It added that Ben Ali's resignation
column2: following his statement that he had been "duped by his entourage"
column3: may not have been entirely sincere. Le Monde criticised French President Nicolas Sarkozy and the European Union's "Silence over the Tragedy" when the unrest broke. The Christian Science Monitor suggested that mobile telecommunications played an influential role in the "revolution".The revolt in Tunisia began speculation that the Tunisian Jasmine Revolution would lead to protests against the multiple other autocratic regimes across the Arab world. This was most famously captured in the phrase asking whether "Tunisia is the Arab Gdańsk?". The allusion refers to the Polish Solidarity movement and Gdańsk's role as the birthplace of the movement that ousted Communism in Eastern Europe. The phrase appeared in outlets such as the BBC
column4: as well as editorials by columnists Rami Khouri and Roger Cohen.Larbi Sadiki suggested that although "conventional wisdom has it that 'terror' in the Arab world is monopolised by al-Qaeda in its various incarnations"
column5: there was also the fact that "regimes in countries like Tunisia and Algeria have been arming and training security apparatuses to fight Osama bin Laden [but] were [still] caught unawares by the 'bin Laden within': the terror of marginalisation for the millions of educated youth who make up a large portion of the region's population. The winds of uncertainty blowing in the Arab west – the Maghreb – threaten to blow eastwards towards the Levant as the marginalised issue the fatalistic scream of despair to be given freedom and bread or death." A similar opinion by Lamis Ardoni carried by Al Jazeera said that the protests had "brought down the walls of fear
column7: thus restoring the Arab peoples' faith in their ability to demand social justice and end tyranny." He also said that the protests that succeeded in toppling the leadership should serve as a "warning to all leaders
column8: whether supported by international or regional powers
column9: that they are no longer immune to popular outcries of fury" even though Tunisia's ostensible change "could still be contained or confiscated by the country's ruling elite
column10: which is desperately clinging to power." He called the protests the "Tunisian intifada" which had "placed the Arab world at a crossroads". He further added that if the change was ultimately successful in Tunisia it could "push the door wide open to freedom in Arab world. If it suffers a setback we shall witness unprecedented repression by rulers struggling to maintain their absolute grip on power. Either way
column11: a system that combined a starkly unequal distribution of wealth with the denial of freedoms has collapsed."Similarly
column12: Mark LeVine noted that the events in Tunisia could spiral into the rest of the Arab world as the movement was "inspiring people...to take to the streets and warn their own sclerotic and autocratic leaders that they could soon face a similar fate." He then cited solidarity protests in Egypt where protesters chanted "Kefaya" and "We are next
column14: Ben Ali tell Mubarak he is next;" and that Arab bloggers were supporting the movement in Tunisia as "the African revolution commencing...the global anti-capitalist revolution." He concluded that there were two scenarios that could play out: "a greater democratic opening across the Arab world
column15: or a similar situation to Algeria in the early 1990s when the democratic election was annulled and Algeria went into a civil war.Robert Fisk asked if this was The end of the age of dictators in the Arab world?" and partly answered the question in saying that Arab leaders would be "shaking in their boots". A blog associated with Wired described the intricate efforts of the Tunisian authorities to control such online media as Twitter and Facebook. Other regional regimes were also on higher alert to contain spillover effects that might have ensued.
